title: Friday, 8th April, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE

BE

BE

Will join shortly, I'm sure.

BE

Or rather, part of a peculiar bar group that floated a while back and absolutely stunk the place out.

BE

http://www.investe...1604080700075770U/

11:09 am
BE

Eclectic Bar Group plc (AIM: BAR) ("Eclectic", the "Company" or, together with its Subsidiaries, the "Group" or the "Existing Group") announces that it has today entered into a conditional agreement to acquire The Brighton Marine Palace and Pier Company, which owns and operates Brighton Pier, a profitable and cash-generative landmark seafront visitor attraction and entertainment venue on the South East coast of the UK, for a total cash consideration of £18 million on a cash-free, debt-free basis.

The Company proposes to fund the consideration payable under the Acquisition through a conditional placing of new Ordinary Shares to raise gross proceeds of not less than £8.5 million, with the balance to be funded through new £13 million debt financing agreed with Barclays Bank plc.

The Acquisition constitutes a reverse takeover for the purposes of Rule 14 of the AIM Rules for Companies and, as such, is conditional, inter alia, upon Shareholder approval.

In addition, Reuben Harley, the Company's Chief Executive Officer, has informed the Board that he intends to step down from the Board following the completion of the Acquisition and intends to sell up to 1,853,795 existing Ordinary Shares pursuant to the Placing.

BE

Jump through to the full statement for some fascinating detail about the financial powerhouse that is Brighton Pier.

BE

Deal's at 5.1x EBITDA to Oct-15, incidentally.

BE

11:19 am
BE

11:21 am
BE

OPEC slushy?

BE

Skepticism is rational
Skepticism is the most rational response to producer negotiations in the lead
up to the 17 April talks in Doha. Although market expectations of a ‘freeze exIran ex-Libya’ have risen, such an agreement would do little to change the
supply outlook. Without the participation of Iran and Libya, production could
extend its 1.6 mmb/d increase since the historic ‘quota hold’ in November
2014. The Kuwaiti suggestion that production could be held at a Jan-Feb
average level does not help very much since February OPEC production was
down only 90 kb/d from January, a seven-year high (32.7 mmb/d).
Positioning tells a different story
Brent non-commercial positioning tells a different story, however, which is that
despite the apparently unproductive nature of such producer meetings, the risk
of low-probability, high-impact outcomes has detracted from the appeal of
holding short positions. Non-commercial short positioning in Brent crude oil
has fallen steadily since 19 January from 420 thousand contracts to 295
thousand contracts, raising net long positioning to a two-year high.
OPEC increase still likely although modest
Iran has been steadfast in its refusal to participate in any agreement, although
it will attend the talks, while Libya does not plan to attend. Without the
participation of the two countries with the most capacity headroom, a
production ‘freeze’ is a misnomer at best. Rising OPEC production over a
twelve month horizon remains strong probability in a freeze excluding Iran and
Libya, although unplanned outages and Iraqi spending reductions will mean
that increases to OPEC volume will be much smaller than last year’s ramp.
Risk that Libyan production may rise
Greater risks for increased OPEC supply over the medium term may now
originate from Libya, although some obstacles remain. The national divide
between two competing governments shows signs of abating amid hopes for
the success of a U.N.-backed political transition. Although prospects remain
unclear, the most positive sign comes from yesterday’s agreement by the
Tripoli-based government to relinquish power, which may pave the way for an
eventual rehabilitation of oil infrastructure and exports.
Neutral Zone upside may be throttled by a freeze
Production from the Partitioned Neutral Zone (PNZ) shared between Saudi
Arabia and Kuwait has been depressed owing to an environmental violation
and a contract dispute. Total production from the region was 520 kb/d as late
as April 2014. While the offshore portion of the zone may be restarted this will
occur in “in small quantities” according to the Kuwait oil minister, and any
volume may be throttled by a freeze agreement as both Saudi Arabia and
Kuwait are likely to participate in a deal.
Fundamental impact of agreement likely to be small
The agitation surrounding the upcoming meeting will amount to little more
than noise, particularly as a production cut has fallen off the agenda, in our
view. Perhaps the most market-positive aspect is simply that as many as
thirteen producer countries may come to any agreement at all. Leaving aside
the infinitesimally small chance of a freeze which includes Iran and Libya, we
expect little impact to either prices or fundamentals. Our central case remains
that even in the absence of producer discipline, a process of rebalancing is
nevertheless underway on the basis of non-OPEC curtailment and steady
demand growth. Downside risks include the possibility that a resolution of
unplanned outages and increases in Iran, Libya and the Neutral Zone may
exceed our OPEC assumption of 33.1 mmb/d in 2017.

BE

Phew. Finally.

11:22 am
undefined
BE

But back to Tullow, and its broken ship.

BE

The turret won't turn

11:23 am
BE

Jubilee production bumps lower

BE

Insurance covers the cost

BE

But the binary issue of Tullow's balance sheet becomes .. even ........... more ....... binary?

11:24 am
BE

Credit Suisse to summarise where we are.

BE

■ Jubilee turret issue confirmed: Damage to the turret bearing on the FPSO
Kwame Nkrumah means it is no longer able to rotate as originally designed.
Production can continue under revised operating and off-take procedures,
whereby tugs are used to minimise vessel movement around the bearing and
a dynamically-positioned shuttle tanker is used in conjunction with a storage
tanker for off-take. Necessary equipment for these procedures is already in
place, and the company anticipates production will restart in ~2 weeks time
after required approvals are received. These changes will likely impact
production guidance for Jubilee, but the company has decided to wait and
see how efficient these new procedures are before updating guidance.
■ Several potential permanent solutions have been identified, and initial
feasibility studies suggest the issue can be fully resolved. It is likely to take
another 2-3 months to select a final repair concept, after which we expect it
to take 9-12 months to implement (exact timing depends on which solution is
picked) – i.e. the issue should be resolved 12-15 months from now.
■ Insurance claims underway: Tullow has both hull and machinery (for fixed
assets eg. FPSO), and business interruption insurance, which should help to
cover the cost of repairing the FPSO, and recover revenue from lost
production. We understand that Tullow has sufficient business interruption
insurance to cover most, if not all of the repair period. Note the company has
stated that it does not expect the issue will have a material impact on its
revenue given the ability to continue production and insurance policies.
■ No change to 270p TP; maintain Outperform: Our financial model has yet
to be updated for likely operational guidance changes, but our TP should not
be impacted provided insurance covers the cost of repairs and lost revenue,
which is our base case.

BE

And Jefferies, which has been giving the company an earful.

11:25 am
BE

Speaking to the company at length this morning (COO) the timeline for resolution is 2-3 months to decide on 1 of 3 engineering solutions and 9-12 months to implement the chosen one:

Replace the necessary parts of the Turret in-field to allow it to rotate once more. Essentially this would be fabricating and installing a new rotational ball-bearing race above the old one. One has to appreciate the size of these parts to understand the engineering this would require.
Convert the Jubilee FPSO to a “spread moored anchor set up” essentially by-passing the need to rotate around a Turret. Currently, 2 tug boats (and a 3rd on standby) are effectively doing this job - holding the FPSO on a fixed heading - because with the turret unable to rotate, any rotational movement of the FPSO (due to sea current/wind etc) places huge stresses on the Turret anchor chains. (we are available to explain in more detail).
Bring the FPSO into dock and replace the entire Turret. In our view, the apparent scale of the engineering involved would make this solution the most realistic (and safest) long term option.

BE

These are all major projects in themselves but as ever with hardware issues we are confident the engineers will resolve the problem and crucially, it is not a reservoir problem. However, regardless of insurance recovery possibilities the Turret situation does impact asset value. For example, we find it hard to imagine the Jubilee Full Field Development plan will be sanctioned until the production facility (FPSO) is fully resolved. Ironically, we had already seen that sanction at risk of further delay simply due to TLW drive to reduce overall group capex.

Production guidance will be reissued once the new off-take procedures are confirmed as working (101kb/d Jubilee gross prior to shut-in TLW 35%, KOS US 24%, APC US 24%). With on-going RBL debt re-redetermination process (end April for news) and ND/EBITDAX reaching 6.5x by 1H16 on our numbers (before the turret issue), we see further risk to the shares despite the insurance claims already field. We recently Downgraded TLW to Underperform specifically due to news of this Turret issue adding to operational issues at Jubilee since First Oil at end-2010. Our Core NAV for TLW (mostly all Ghana value) is 115p/sh. To get to our target price of 166p a further 56p of East Africa "upside" is required.

BE

Analyst is Mark Wilson.

11:26 am
BE

And Niki Kouzmanov.

undefined
BE

Okay, so we're down 50% on the left side of the page and down about 70% on the right side.

11:27 am
BE

I know it's not an exciting day, ROTR, but jeez .............

BE

In terms of the sellside, the only call worth noting really is on Elementis.

BE

(@Cheecky: ship's broke.)

11:29 am
BE

Which is a Berenberg downgrade.

Elementis PLC (ELM:LSE): Last: 220.00, down 18.6 (-7.80%), High: 235.90, Low: 216.60, Volume: 985.81k
BE

On valuation, chromium.

11:31 am
BE

● Downgrade to Hold on valuation, chromium: We reduce our rating to
Hold, and cut our price target by GBp38 to GBp220. Since our upgrade to
Buy on 30 October 2015 (Look beyond oilfield business; up to Buy),
Elementis has outperformed the Stoxx Europe 600 Chemicals (SX4P) index
by c12%, re-rating c1.5x turns on a 12-month forward P/E basis to just over
16.5x. The primary reasons for this are: i) dividend support (2016 yield of
4.2% is a third higher than the SX4P, and could rise further); and ii) an
apparent stabilisation in oilfield volumes. However, a full-looking
valuation and additional headwinds in chromium leave us more cautious.

BE

See?

BE

● Chromium headwinds in 2016 and beyond: In our view, consensus
estimates have underestimated the scale of the potential reduction in
pricing and margins within Elementis’ chromium division. We think
Elementis will continue to lose market share in Europe and Asia-Pacific to
FX-advantaged players such as Kazchrome and Russian Chrome, which
appear to still have some spare capacity. Structural advantages in the US
market (c60% of the division’s sales) appear safe for the time being. But
short term, pressure on chromium chemical prices (down c7% in 2015) will
weigh on chromium sales (-2.4% for 2016E) and adjusted EBIT, where we a
see a further 1.5% reduction versus 2015, to 22.5%. Longer term, we think
Elementis will have to avoid pricing increases in the US to deter foreign
entrants, meaning lower chromium margins could become structural.

11:31 am
BE

● Oilfield stabilised, but unlikely to show significant growth: Following a
volume-driven 38% decline in sales over the course of 2015, Elementis’
oilfield chemicals business has now stabilised. This segment appears to
have found a cUSD10m/quarter niche for high-value fracks. But the
continued decline in the US rig count (-30% ytd) and the muted outlook for
oil prices is likely to limit longer-term volume growth.

BE

(@cheecky: well, they definitely bought a ship, so perhaps that's the problem.)

BE

● Estimates changes: Our 2016 and 2017 EPS estimates fall by 6.3% and 4.6%
respectively to reflect lower margins in chromium, and a reduction in the
expected post-2016 volume growth of the oilfield business (from 10% to
3%). We are c4-5.5% below consensus at the adjusted EPS level for 2016-18.
● Cash provides valuation support: Elementis faces structural headwinds in
its most profitable segment (chromium), and has a valuation above both
historical 10-year average (13x) and sector average (14.5x) 12-month
forward P/E. Yet while valuation looks more than full on a P/E basis,
downside is, in our view, limited by the stock’s dividend yield. At our price
target of GBp220, 2016 dividend yield would be c4.5%, a c45% premium to
the SX4P. Yields could rise to c10% on our numbers if Elementis decides to
make additional returns of up to USD100m to shareholders.

11:04 am
BE

Welcome to Friday.

BE

Today's UK trade and industrial data mentioned

BE

Industrial reads -0.3% vs a +0.1% consensus

11:34 am
BE

Trade balance -£4.8bn vs -£3.4bn consensus

BE

So ...... ugly.

BE

Here's Berenberg (again!) to take us through the detail.

11:35 am
BE

Industrial weakness could present some downside risk to first quarter growth. Industrial output declined by 0.3% mom in February, against consensus expectations of a modest rise of 0.1%. Comparing the first two months of the year to the final quarter of 2015 shows industrial output declined by 1.0%. Is this a serious cause for concern for the wider economy? No. But it does suggest that risks to our outlook for first quarter growth of 0.4% are tilted to the downside. The export oriented industrial sector only makes up around 15% of GDP. As long as the domestic economy remains resilient, declines in this relatively small sector tend to inflict only minor damage to the headline rate. Data for manufacturing, the largest component of industrial output, declined by 1.1% mom versus expectations of -0.2%.

BE

UK trade deficit more than £1 billion wider than expected after a sharp downward revision to January data. The UK’s trade deficit was -£4.8bn in February, far above consensus expectations of -£3.4b. With January data getting a sharp downward revision to -£5.2b from the previous estimate of -£3.5b, this puts the UK on a concerning course to beat its record current account deficit (7% of GDP) in the final quarter of last year. In the three months to February, the UK’s deficit to the rest of the EU reached a record £23.8bn. This was driven by a rise in imports of 1.1% and a fall in exports of 1.3%

Swelling trade deficit adds to UK current account troubles ahead of EU referendum. In recent years, the combination of weaker exports of goods to the EU alongside a fall in the returns the UK gets on its overseas investments has grown the UK’s current account deficit from a modest problem to a serious one. In the final quarter of last year, the UK ran the largest current account deficit on record at 7% of GDP (see chart). The UK’s current account deficit is the biggest in the G7 and, heading into the EU referendum on the 23 June, it is a growing cause for concern. We see the risk of a Brexit at 35%. If a Brexit does happen, the is a risk that if investors suddenly fear that, because of the negative economic effects of a Brexit, the UK can no longer meet its obligations later on without a massive devaluation, they might attempt to exit their sterling positions in a hurry. This gives way to our key Brexit tail risk. Although it remains a low probability event and is not our central forecast, we pay close attention to the risk of a sterling crisis.

BE

And a chart ....

11:37 am
BE

BE

Hey, speaking of Brexit .....

BE

Deutsche updates its models.

11:39 am
BE

 At the front end, the market continues to attach a Brexit premium to the
money market curve, pricing a first hike in H1 2020 and a ~45% chance of
cuts by the end of this year.
 In a vote to remain in the EU, a hawkish re-pricing of the BoE’s path would
lead to significant re-steepening. On the other hand, in an “out” vote the
market is currently pricing the trough in sonia only at the December
meeting. This would imply the MPC delays almost six months following a
vote to leave before easing which, in our view, is excessive. To capture
the steepening pressures of these contrasting dynamics we recommend
August-December MPC date sonia steepeners.
 Further out the curve, the EU referendum has led to a front loading of
issuance over April and May. Looking to the long end, this month’s reopening of the UKT 2.5% 2065 is likely to require further concession, while
there remains potential for a repeat of late February’s supply indigestion.
As a result, we move underweight the UK long end into this period of
higher issuance, and go short 50Y spreads.

BE

Wee bit more detail in that, for those who don't speak credit.

BE

In the case where the UK votes to leave, the market currently expects a dovish
Bank of England reaction, with ~1 1 bp of cuts priced into the sonia curve by
the December MPC meeting. From a policy perspective, the initial dovish
response to Brexit-related concerns is likely be in the form of a cut to the base
rate, with the MPC then shifting towards further QE purchases rather to avoid
approaching negative rate territory. Indeed, such a restarting of the asset
purchase facility would also be beneficial in the event that a Brexit led to
outflows from non-resident investors, with central bank purchases
compensating for potential capital flight.
The market is pricing a downward sloping money market curve that troughs in
December, suggesting expectations are for the Bank of England to delay any
policy response until the end of 2016.
However, it is not clear the Bank of England would delay until the end of the
year if the MPC thought dovish policy action following a Brexit vote was
warranted. Indeed, following the June vote, data from July onwards will begin
to capture the early impact of a vote to leave on the macro outlook. In
particular, consumer and business confidence surveys would be likely to show
the first indications of any post-vote headwinds, while PMIs together with
other survey measures would likely pick up signs of any slowdown from
August onwards.

11:40 am
BE

As a result, following a leave vote the MPC would likely already have
information to judge the need for a dovish reaction was warranted before the
end of summer. Therefore, were a vote to leave indeed take place and the
Bank of England react with a cut to the base rate, the risk is that they would do
so earlier rather than later than the market currently expects.

BE

In our view there is also no requirement for the MPC to wait until an inflation
report in order to cut rates. Indeed, the staff forecasts at the November
Inflation Report are unlikely to provide much additional information relative to
the data already available. What’s more, given a post-vote sterling devaluation
coupled with a rally in front end rates would tend to further support the
inflation trajectory, the forecasts could argue against more dovish policy.
Therefore, following a vote to exit the risks are skewed towards a dovish
reaction sooner rather than later, suggesting a steepening of the very front end
money market curve.
Given the current trough in sonia in Dec-16, we recommend an AugustDecember MPC date sonia steepener. This should benefit from a) more preemptive MPC easing than currently priced in a Brexit scenario and b) the
potential for a re-steepening of the curve should the UK vote to remain.

undefined
11:42 am
BE

"Scratching about like an old wet hen," an editor of mine used to say each Friday morning.

BE

Just remembered that. Feels appropriate today.

BE

Vectura, though, has been mentioned on the right.

11:43 am
BE

This is post the FDA accepting its filing for clone Advair

Vectura Group PLC (VEC:LSE): Last: 169.61, up 6.81 (+4.18%), High: 173.50, Low: 167.00, Volume: 993.66k
BE

Which is an incremental positive, in the sense that it's expected but an expected thing actually happening isn't a negative.

11:44 am
BE

If you follow.

BE

It also gives RBC an excuse to retread the buy case.

BE

l The FDA has accepted Vectura and commercial partner Hikma’s filing of AB-rated Advair in the US with a goal GDUFA date of 10 May; whilst the
acceptance date has come within our timeline expectations the potential approval date is slightly (1 -2 months) earlier than we had anticipated. We had
already assumed a Q3 launch and, with the timeline now set by the FDA, there is a risk to the upside that the launch comes earlier than we had original
anticipated (we prefer to leave some headroom in our estimates, for now).

11:45 am
BE

l Vectura is eligible for a $10m milestone payment from Hikma (1p per share on a FD basis post the merger with Skye) and a further $11m upon approval
but, whilst this is only a token value to the company we see greater meaning to Vectura shareholders from the acceptance and, hopefully, approval.
Vectura is set to earn a 15% royalty on sales from a product that is directly substitutable with the gold standard ICS/LABA drug (Advair) for
asthma/COPD in the US which is still generating $3bn of revenues and with only 1 -2 other generic competitors likely. It is not unreasonable to assume
the product could generate $300m within 24 months of launch, and continuing for c.10 years (providing a healthy £30m p.a. revenue stream at 100%
gross margin). As a reminder Vec’s current Mcap is £650m pre the merger

BE

l No change to forecasts; we had already assumed this event. As a reminder pre-merger FY16E/17E/18E revenue, EBITDA and EPS of £69.8m/£77.4m/
£106.5m, £23.9m/£25.8m/£51.7m and 4.35p/5.10p/10.64p respectively. Post-merger FY16E/17E/18E revenue, EBITDA and EPS of £69.8m/£132.7m/
£239.9m, £23.9m/£42.m/£100.6m and 4.35p/6.37p/12.33p respectively.
l Valuation: Once the product launches we think it adds c25p to the share price (we had already assumed the acceptance) and, if the company begins to
be valued as a fast growing company (with a FCF yield of +8% by that point also) post the merger with Skye then we see upwards of 300p as possible
(basic 20x multiple against FY18E Mar-YE EPS of the combined group plus the cash position (up to £150m by that point, c10% of combined Mcap). We
suggest buying now.

BE

And Numis

11:46 am
BE

In our view, Vectura/Hikma is one of only a few credible
contenders targeting the c.$3bn US market for Advair. We are bullish on the prospects
and assign 75% chance of success, which reflects our confidence in the product
following the update on clinical in January, which we believe indicated that the 1,430
patient trial had been successful in meeting the FDA definition of clinical bioequivalance
(90% confidence intervals of test/reference ratio of endpoints within 80-125%).

BE

$320m of peak sales: We forecast $320m of peak sales for VR315 in the US, reflecting
payer-led substitution of GSK's Advair, and therapeutic substitution from other ICS/
LABA brands (ie Symbicort, Dulera and Breo). If we assume that only 50% of Advair
is substituted, together with 25% of Symbicort and Dulera and 10% of Breo, we derive
a $1.2bn market opportunity if priced at a 33% discount to the brand. With 3-4 players
in the market we see VR315 gaining 25% of this opportunity driving peak sales of
$320m and greater than $45m of potential royalty payments to Vectura that we value at 43p/share
(at 75% risk adjustment) and increasing to 57p/share unrisked. For now, we make no
changes to these assumptions, but this is a key derisking step that should give the
market increased confidence in our growth forecasts for VR315, that underpin our 264p
target price.

BE

Additional catalysts expected in the coming 12 months: In addition to the
anticipated completion of the merger, 2016 should provide numerous additional
catalysts. With regulatory / commercial updates we are focused on Flutiform and
Novartis' EU/RoW sales of Seebri and Ultibro and US progress with Seebri / Utibron.
We also anticipate the first EU approval of the FOX handheld nebuliser, which could
open up new opportunities. Clinical data should start to impact again and here we focus
on the Belgian partners UCB and Ablynx both set to deliver proof of concept data on
delivery of biologics to the lung using Vectura technology. If proven, this could open
up a large market opportunity.

11:48 am

11:56 am
BE

11:57 am

11:58 am

BE

11:58 am
BE

(Though perhaps that too.)

BE

Are we approaching the endgame? It'd be too much to expect that we are, but there's always hope ....

BE

Here's a quick comment from RF Lafferty & Co

12:00 pm
BE

What will a bidder pay for YHOO’s Core Operating Business –There is an argument for attributing a relatively low
4X-5X EBITDA multiple for what is a struggling business characterized by significant profit and cash flow erosion –
Since 2012, the year Marissa Meyer was appointed President & CEO of YHOO, Adjusted EBITDA as reported by the
company has dropped by 44% with a ~15%-20% decline expected for 2016 based on company guidance in spite of
management’s ongoing turnaround efforts. A 4X -5X transaction multiple values the business with at $3-$4 BN range.
But ultimately the bid proposals coming in will depend on the business’s strategic and synergistic value to the bidder. A
more optimistic view on valuation will to look at the most recent comparable transaction, i.e., Verizon’s acquisition of
AOL completed in June 2015 – VZ paid $4.4 BN for a similarly struggling business of about half the size in revenue and
EBITDA at a multiple of 7.5X LTM EBITDA. Bearing in mind that VZ has also expressed interest in the YHOO
business, this type of multiple would put a $5.25-$6 BN transaction value on it based on 2016 EBITDA guidance.

BE

What is the value of the Asian assets to YHOO shareholders – The values of these assets are ostensibly better
crystallized as they are minority stakes in publicly traded entities. However, it is improbable that YHOO shareholders will
be able to realize full market value for the stakes. If they are sold, they potentially attract significant capital gains tax
liabilities - when YHOO first proposed the spin-out of its BABA stake, it estimated that a straight sale would incur a tax
liability of 40%, while it is also expected that the sale of its 35% equity interest in Yahoo Japan would also incur a
material liability. If these assets remain unsold, the YHOO stub (ex its Core Operating business) simply becomes a
passive HoldingCo for minority stakes in publicly traded entities which can be expected to trade at a discount to its
underlying SOTP.
